body.p: The Life of the Single Sister Sarh Craven who departed in Fulneck Novr 10th 1790.

I was born at Rothwel near Leeds in Yorkshire Novr: 11th 1719 and Liv'd with my Parents till my Father died who belong'd to the Church of England. When I was a Child I often wish'd to die, for I thought at that age I shou'd be saved; but if I liv'd to grow up to be a Woman I should come into things which would hinder me from attaining eternal happiness. When I came into riper years I follow'd the World with eagerness, tho not with satisfaction for I often felt uneasy in my mind, but put it off, resolving to grow better, but still went on in my old way. After my Father's death I went to live with my Uncle, and was with him when Mr Ingham came into those parts, but soon after went to live with my Mother: she ask'd me to go with her to hear him Preach, but I declin'd it for this reason, I believ'd if I was one of his followers I must renounce the World; which was my cheif Object at that time Soon after he came again to preach nearer to our habittution; my Mother urged me to go with her which I could not help complying with tho, spiritually dead, and the discourse had no effect, and I wonder'd

what induc'd People to run after him, my Mother invited him to Preach at our House but he did not chuse to do it except we would have a Society settled, to which she consented. In the mean time my Mother spoke very closely to me about the state of my Soul; thus prepar'd I went to hear him again, During his Sermon I was made sensible of my last condition, I wish'd I could alter, and thought I had better be depreved, of this Worlds pleasure then love my mortal Soul, I thought I could part with every thing I had in the World to be assur'd of my Salvation; but fear'd it was impossible. In this miserable state I continued a long time and came into self working. by degrees my misery worse off and I concluded this was the right way to do all the good that was in my power, so my conscience was to be appeased, but being of a hasty temper and sometimes overcome with passion, my good oppinion of my self vanish'd and I became miserable again. In the Year 1740. Mr. Ingham and Br Teltshig came to our house, the latter could not speak English, but his look made a particular impression on me and I believed him to be indeed a Child of God. In a short time after this Visit out Society was dispers'd which troubled me very much. One of them and myself desir'd to be admitted into another Society wich was soon after the case with a small company at Holbeck near Leeds; But not having the pleasure to see Brn & Srs often, I grew dry in my heart, Upon being ask'd to be Servant in a Family, I at first

refused but being earnestly intreated I at last accepted and went to the place. I was very uneasy in it for I found. I had no freedom to mix in worldly company, but was Oblidged to stay my time out. The night before I left my place, I drew that Verse, When I was lost and far had stray'd. Into a Desart wild & the day after when I was with my Mother some Sisters came to see me, I told them what had pass'd, they advised me to make a new begining and then our Saviour and the Brn would forgive me these words comforted me for I did not expect to hear such from them. The first meeting I went to after their Visit, Br Telstig kept on the following words" ye cannot serve two Masters "it seem'd as if he directed his discourse to me alone and I determin'd to have our Saviour alone for my Master. a short time after I was advised to live with two Sisters in Holbeck, I did so, but my sittuation was not at first agreable to me, I did not remain long with them being desir'd by Br Tiltsheg to go to Leeds to wait on a Sick Sister, but soon became sick myself, as I had then no money left to help me I was persuaded to live with my Mother with whom I remain'd till she died. The day before she departed a Sister visited her & asked her where she would like to have me sittuated; she reply'd, among the Sisters, But after her death I felt such a strong attachment to my Relations that I thought I could not part with them, which brought me again into trouble and quite at a loss what to do, When I was by my self my faithful Monitor convinc'd me once more that I was not in my right place; to stay then would be dangerous for my Soul. I immediately set off to acquaint

my former Laboress and disclos'd my whole case, She recomended me to another Family in Holbeck, this was in the Year 1750 I attended the Preaching in Fulneck every Sunday. Br LaTrobe Sermons were a real blessings to me and I frequently imagin'd that he knew my inmost thoughts, I had no rest day nor night on account of the burden of my sins, One day as I was by myself earnestly entreating our Saviour to manifest himself unto me, he granted, my request and gave me a full assurance of the for giveness of my sins, which came with such power that it melted me into tears. from this time and particularly during my stay in that Family, I received many blessings from our Savior, This was a particular period with the Brethrens Congregation, their enemies in these parts where not affraid to prognasticate their ruin notwithstanding this I wish'd for a still closer union with them and importun'd to be a member of the Congn The two Srs with whom I Liv'd having departed this Life it was thought proper for me to leave Holbeck and I was placed at last to my great joy in the Single Srs Oeconomy at Gomersal May 20th 1755, and was soon at home with them, tho, it prov'd a new school for my heart. The 3d of March 1756 I was inform'd would be a general Congregation Day. I got an impression on that day I should have the favor to be added thereto, I therfore kept a band with our Savior sensible of my poverty and helplessness yet comforted with his nearness.
In this Sittuation of mind according to my impression I was received into the Congn on the above mentioned day which prov'd a great blessing to me Thus far her own account

April 20th 1756 our late Sister remov'd from Gommersal to live in the Choir House here. March 21st 1757 she partook of the holy Communion with the Congregation for the first time, It was evident notwithstanding all human imperfection that she had found her peace with our Savior. She knew in whom she beleivd and was perswaded that he was able to keep that which she had comitted unto him this help'd her through every trying circumstance she met with; her call to the Congn of Jesus she value'd highly and often spoke of it with the greatest gratitude It was a particular pleasure to her to serve her Sisters in any little matters she was able to do which she did with great faithfulness as long as her strength would admitt of it. The begingning of this Year an Asmatick complaint which she had labor'd under many years grew very troublesome to her, so that She was oblidg'd in Jany to move into the sick room, when her longing to be at home with our Savior increased daily. It gave her much pain when two of her companions in the Sick

room were called home before her, she suffer'd much in her sick, ness which made her sometimes rather impatient and think the time long, but she would soon recollect herself again and in treated our Savior to give her a Childlike resignation to his will that she might not greive him by her impatience. The night before her departure, she said I am waiting for our Saviour to come and fetch her me, he will not be long now before he comes I shall then see him for my self; sickness and sorow will have an end, He will wipe all tears from my Eyes. that night she spent in great Weakness but in converse with her best Freind Novr 10th the happy moment came when she departed in a soft and easy manner to her dear Redeemer with the blessing of her Choir half past 10 oclock in the forenoon during a sensible feeling of our dear Lords presence, in the 72nd Year of her Age.
